nodes.text: Hey, Commander. Can I help you with something?

branches.responseText: We're free agents again. What do you want to do now?
I've got some questions about navigation.
I'm collecting stories about the crew. Tell me something about yourself.
I've gotta get back to it. Talk to you later, Sumire.

nodes.text:
Get rich. Earn enough money to roll around in. Stock the galley with [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreCassilda],Cassildan]] clam steaks and kegs of [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreTimbiquiDark],Timbiqui Dark]].

Do you want me to keep going? I can keep going.

branches.responseText: Go ahead. These are all good suggestions—I'm taking notes.
I'm morbidly curious to see how far you take this, Meyer.
That's okay, Sumire. I think I get the picture.

nodes.text: I want more comedy Holovids in the rec room. None of that action or horror stuff that Darius likes. Those weird Lyran cartoons that Farah's obsessed with are okay on occasion, but she has, like, a thousand of them, and a girl can only take so much. Speaking of the rec room, doesn't it feel… I dunno… cold to you? Some hardwood furnishings would help. I'm thinking mahogany, or teak. We could panel the walls with it and pretend that we're in [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreHanseDavion],Hanse Davion's]] reading room.

I trust that you can see where I'm going with this. I don't care where our travels take us, or who we get our jobs from.

I don't need to go thrill-seeking—I get all the adventure I need on a daily basis.

What I do want is money, and all the creature comforts that come with it. I want to buy ridiculous, frivolous things that are totally unrelated to our survival, without having to feel bad about it afterward. You give me that, and you'll have a happy navigator.
Then buckle in, 'cause you ain't heard nothin' yet.

Good, I'm glad my point is coming across. See, I don't particularly care where our travels take us, or who we get our jobs from.

I don't need to go thrill-seeking—I get all the adventure I need on a daily basis.

Hey, Commander. It feels like our fortunes are beginning to turn.

It's about time, I've gotta say.

branches.responseText: Well, we aren't at war with the Taurians anymore.
I've got some questions about navigation.
I'm collecting stories about the crew. Tell me something about yourself.
I've gotta get back to it. Talk to you later, Sumire.

nodes.text:
No, we're not. I owe Lord Madeira one for that… I guess we all do. Maybe even more importantly—to me, anyway—is that the [[DM.Factions[faction_TaurianConcordat],Taurians]] are dialing down tensions with the [[DM.Factions[faction_Davion],Federated Suns]].

It's hard to believe how close we came to something truly awful happening.

Anyway, it seems unlikely now, and that's a pretty huge weight off my shoulders. I may not live in the Concordat anymore, but I still love my homeland. …I mean, not the birds, but everything else.

And [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreThomasCalderon],Protector Calderon]] isn't as bad as he's been made out to be, either. He has his quirks, but he's done a lot for the Taurian people since he took power. Hopefully the rest of his reign will be long and peaceful.

Who knows? With luck, maybe the Concordat and the Reach will be friends some day. You know, with trade, and open borders… that kind of thing. Lady Arano did help Calderon, and that was after he sent a vengeance-obsessed maniac to murder her. You never know how things will work out, is what I'm saying. And for now, I'm gonna hang onto the hope that they get better again before they get worse.
That bastard poisoned my people. Espinosa. He murdered eleven thousand Taurians to sign a damned treaty. I already had plenty of reasons to hate the man, but now? Now I'm going to spit on his grave.

branches.responseText: I'd like to talk about what we saw in Lord Madeira's evidence.
I've got some questions about navigation.
I'm collecting stories about the crew. Tell me something about yourself.
I've gotta get back to it. Talk to you later, Sumire.

nodes.text: Yeah… me too. Specifically, I'd like to have a nice, long chat about it with [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreThomasCalderon],Protector Calderon]]. And then I'd like to watch him hunt Director Espinosa down. That monster committed mass murder on [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LorePerdition],Perdition]]. He had eleven thousand of my people poisoned to death and let the Federated Suns take the blame.

There's a special place in hell for people like Espinosa.

With luck, we'll get to help send him there.

The Argo is hosed, a bunch of Lord Karosas's people are dead, and we're apparently at war with the [[DM.Factions[faction_TaurianConcordat],Taurian Concordat]]. I wish I could say that it surprised me that this drop went to shit, but… nope! Not surprised at all.

branches.responseText: You know ships, and you grew up in the Concordat. I need to know what we're up against.
I've got some questions about navigation.
I'm collecting stories about the crew. Tell me something about yourself.
I've gotta get back to it. Talk to you later, Sumire.

nodes.text: A world of hurt, Commander. A world of hurt. Commodore Ostergaard's command ship, the Iberia, is a Fortress-class DropShip. They don't call 'em that for nothing. Do you have any idea how many weapons one of those things comes equipped with?

First, there's the Long Tom III artillery cannon… you've already seen what that can do. If you somehow survive that, you've got six PPCs, four LRM-20s, four LRM-10s, and eight Large Lasers to deal with. If, through some miraculous twist of fate, you manage to live through all of that, then the Fortress still has five AC/5s, six SRM-6s, sixteen Medium Lasers, and a pair of AC/20s to murder you with.

Long story short, Commander? Nothing gets close to a Fortress and lives. It can run its guns all day long without overheating or running out of ammo, and it can obliterate any 'Mech you throw at it without breaking a sweat.

Oh, and it also carries a full combined-arms battalion of infantry, vehicles, and 'Mechs.
I guess what I'm saying is, if the Iberia wants you dead, you're dead. Your only real option is to be where it isn't. End of story.

Well. I guess we're going hunting for [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreLosTech],LosTech]].

Hooray.

branches.responseText: What do you think of the plan to raid Castle Nautilus?
I've got some questions about navigation.
I'm collecting stories about the crew. Tell me something about yourself.
I've gotta get back to it. Talk to you later, Sumire.

nodes.text: Oh, I think I made my feelings on the matter pretty clear. It's a bad idea. No, scratch that. It's a shockingly bad idea. We should be focusing on the war against the Directorate. Instead, we're taking a massive diversion and heading to the middle of Directorate space, where we'll dig for buried treasure that might or might not kill us.

…Look. I know that everybody's really excited about the prospect of finding [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreSLDF],Star League Defense Force]] BattleMechs. And I do get what that would mean.

But… seriously, Commander. We're betting an awful lot on a hunch, don't you think?

branches.responseText: Doesn't matter what I think. It isn't my decision to make.
If there's even a chance that we'll find LosTech at Castle Nautilus, I'm all for checking it out.
Between you and me? I agree with you. But our client thinks differently.

nodes.text:
Yeah. I get that. And obviously, we have to do what our incredibly wealthy client wants.

I dunno. If this thing goes off without a hitch and we wind up with a hold full of priceless BattleMechs, I'll be the first to say I'm sorry. I guess we'll just have to wait and see.

That's that, then, isn't it? You and Lady Arano have me outranked and outnumbered.

We're going to Artru, whether I like it or not. I get that, and I'll do my job, same as I always do. But I reserve the right to say "I told you so" if this mission blows up in our faces.
Commander {COMMANDER.LastName}. What's up?

branches.responseText: What do you think of the Argo? You gonna be able to fly this beast?
I've got some questions about navigation.
I'm collecting stories about the crew. Tell me something about yourself.
I've gotta get back to it. Talk to you later, Sumire.

nodes.text:
She's… different. Piloting her won't be a problem, but I can't say I'm happy about living on a piece of [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreLosTech],LosTech]]. Too many question marks for my taste.

That said, I get the necessity—the Leopard is just too damned small.

Anyway. As long as we're all able to restrain ourselves from pushing any mysterious buttons, we should be okay. That's what I keep telling myself, anyway. And life aboard the Argo should continue to improve as Dr. Murad brings new sections of the ship online, so we've got that to look forward to.

branches.responseText: This ship has potential, I'll give her that.
We've got higher priorities than decking out the Argo, I'm afraid.
You've got that right. I'm gonna fix this bucket up the first chance I get.

nodes.text:
Yeah, and I can't wait to see how she develops over time.

Personally, I'm rooting for a day spa, but I'm easy. I'll take what I can get.

That's your call to make, Commander… but if you ever change your mind, I want a movie theater. And a day spa. Maybe a designated cocktail lounge in aft storage.

There are things you could do, is what I'm saying. Just putting that out there.

Sounds like a plan to me… can't wait to see what you do with the place.

Personally, I'm rooting for a day spa, but I'm easy. I'll take what I can get.
Commander {COMMANDER.LastName}. What's up?

branches.responseText: You did good work back on Axylus. If you hadn't gotten Dr. Murad and her crew down safely, none of us would've made it off of that rock.
I've got some questions about navigation.
I'm collecting stories about the crew. Tell me something about yourself.
I've gotta get back to it. Talk to you later, Sumire.

nodes.text:
Just doing my job, Commander. You MechWarriors are the ones who take all the real risks. …Actually, I take that back. This job put all of us at risk.

You know what I'm talking about. The [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LorePiratePoint],Pirate Point]].

I don't know how much you know about [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreMisjump],misjumps]], but, well… they're really, really bad. You could wind up in the heart of a star, or in the middle of nowhere, crashed on some godforsaken rock—with my luck, a rock that's infested with fetid, screeching, mite-infested birds.

branches.responseText: C'mon, Meyer. That sounds a little far-fetched.
Let's just be glad that didn't happen.

nodes.text:
Maybe, maybe not. Look, it was an unbelievably risky jump—that's all I'm saying.

I'm just glad that we all made it through in one piece.
Oh, believe me, I'm glad. I like myself in one piece, and I'd prefer it if I could stay that way.

Well, I've gotta hand it to Darius… he did it. The XO found us a client.

Whether she is what she claims to be remains to be seen. But she's a client, and she has money. That's a start.

branches.responseText: You got any thoughts about working for Lady Centrella?
I've got some questions about navigation.
I'm collecting stories about the crew. Tell me something about yourself.
I've gotta get back to it. Talk to you later, Sumire.

nodes.text: I think she's rich. That's the only qualification a client needs in my book.

…It's funny. There was a time where I'd find working for a Centrella unthinkable. The [[DM.Factions[faction_MagistracyOfCanopus],Magistracy of Canopus]] doesn't have the best reputation where I grew up. But in the grand scheme of things, childhood prejudices are no match for economic necessity.

Hell, I'd work for [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreStefanAmaris],Stefan Amaris]] if he paid me well enough.

branches.responseText: I can see why the mercenary life appeals to you.
Amaris is one of the most reviled figures in history, Meyer.
Hey, I'm right there with you. I'll go wherever the money is.

nodes.text:
Yeah… I kind of wear it on my sleeve, don't I?

Whatever. We're all in this for the money. I just choose to be honest about it.
Yup. And his C-Bills would be just as good as anyone else's.
I knew there was a reason I liked you.
Hey, Commander. Something I can do for you?

branches.responseText: Does the decision we made about uncertified contracts satisfy your concerns?
branches.comment: If User is not in Career Mode

branches.responseText: I've got some questions about navigation.
I'm collecting stories about the crew. Tell me something about yourself.
I've gotta get back to it. Talk to you later, Sumire.

nodes.text:
My concerns won't be satisfied until our creditors have been paid and the loan sharks are off our backs. But this is a step in the right direction, and that makes me happy.

I'm not blind to the risks that uncertified contracts entail, by the way. I mean, I know that what we're doing is dangerous. But it's the best chance we've got to dig ourselves out of this hole.

Sure, ask away.

I mean, it's kind of important that you understand what you're doing, so if I can help with that, I'm all for it.

branches.responseText: <color=#85DBF6FF>[Tutorial: Ship Navigation]</color> Okay, Navigator, how do we get from system to system?
<color=#85DBF6FF>[Tutorial: Star Map]</color> The star map confuses me sometimes. Why does it take longer to get to one place than to another when the systems appear to be the same distance apart?
<color=#85DBF6FF>[Tutorial: Stores and the Hiring Hall]</color> What can I do while we're orbiting in-system?
That's all for now, Sumire. Thanks for the help.

nodes.text:
The short answer is that you pick a destination on the star map, and I make it happen.

Interstellar travel takes time—sometimes weeks—and it'll cost us C-Bills for fuel and passage on a JumpShip, but it's the only way for an outfit like ours to survive out here. We go where the work is.

branches.responseText: What intel can I get about a system before choosing to go there?
What else can you tell me about the mechanics of space travel? I want to know it all.
Do we always have to pay our way from system to system?
I want to ask about something else.

nodes.text:
Enough to make a reasonably informed choice, I think. The star map makes political boundaries clear, so you'll know whose space we're entering.

I've preprogrammed the star map to lock out travel to systems designated as no-fly zones. We're looking for work, not an interstellar incident.

Beyond political boundaries, the nav system will highlight political factions active in the system. That should give you a good idea of who's hiring.

It's probably a good idea to check our reputation with the local factions before ordering a long voyage.

branches.responseText: There's got to be more intel than just the local politics.
I want to ask about something else.

nodes.text:
There is. As you select systems on the star map, you'll see a list of the attributes the MercNet database associates with them.

Attributes like "black market" or "poor" are clues to local store contents, the type of mercs we'll find in hiring halls, contracts we may be offered, and potential mission environments. If you hover over an attribute, the star map will display a longer description for you.

Beyond the political factions and attributes of a system, perhaps the most important to watch for is the difficulty rating of the merc contracts we'll find there.

The MRB maintains a standardized rating system, so folks like us who're trolling MercNet for jobs can weigh the risks before accepting a contract.
Sure, Commander. What would you like to know?

Well, the long answer is that there's two types of space travel: travel by DropShips like ours, and travel by JumpShips.

DropShips travel under one G of thrust to move from a planet's orbit to a jump point. Jump points are far outside the gravity well of the star, and so travel to and from a jump point takes most of our travel time—sometimes weeks.

JumpShips, on the other hand, are like ferries. They just sit at a jump point waiting for folks like us to latch onto their docking collar. Then we wait there for about five days while they spin up their jump drive.

Once the jump drive is spun up, popping a dozen light-years across interstellar space to another jump point takes nearly no time at all.

branches.responseText: I've heard stories about "pirate points" that a JumpShip can use. What are those?
I want to ask about something else.

nodes.text:
They're bad news, Commander. Difficult to locate and dangerous to use. I've heard of people using pirate points in desperate situations or on covert missions, but it's not worth the risk of a misjump.

You won't find any pirate points on my star map, I can tell you that. Let's just avoid 'em.
Sure, Commander. What would you like to know?

Not always, no. If you check the contracts list in the Command Center, you'll often find employers posting travel contracts.

Travel contracts are how employers attract mercenaries to their system—by paying the outfit's travel expenses.

Now, I know what you're thinking—why not take the travel contract and then skip out on their mission for a more lucrative contract when we arrive? You can do that, {COMMANDER.Callsign}, but we'll automatically get charged the cost of the jump.

You know that old saying, "There's no such thing as a free ride"? …Yeah. Unfortunately, it's still true.
Sure, Commander. What would you like to know?

Yeah, that bothered me too before I joined the academy. Turns out that in real life, space travel isn't like what you see in the adventure Holovids that Darius makes us watch. For starters, some stars are more massive than others. In the case of a really big star, you have to range pretty far afield to find a location suitable for a K-F jump. And for us, that means a whole lot of molasses-slow sub-light travel before we can even dock with a JumpShip, let alone ride it anywhere.

JumpShip charging times are the other half of the travel time equation. A JumpShip's K-F drive will take a few days to recharge after each jump, so if your destination is a few jumps away… well, you get where I'm going with this. And that's the long and the short of it. Anytime we want to go from one system to another, we're talking about weeks of sub-light travel, coupled with a healthy dose of hurry-up-and-wait. Exactly how much determines how long the trip is gonna take.

Beyond negotiating a contract? Most inhabited systems maintain a hiring hall where we can recruit new MechWarriors. Be sure to take a look—you never know what kind of talent you're going to find.

Most systems also have merchants who can buy and sell hardware such as weapons, equipment, and 'Mech parts—sometimes even fully operational BattleMechs, too.

Our reputation with the local faction will influence costs when purchasing equipment and hiring MechWarriors.

The better our rep, the better the deal we'll get—and the better the MechWarriors who'll be willing to sign on with us.
Yeah, sure, anytime. Commander Markham never really paid much attention to this kind of stuff, so your interest is a welcome change.

Well… I'm from a noble family, like you. We're old money—made our fortune out in [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreRasalhague],Rasalhague]], then repatriated to the [[DM.Factions[faction_TaurianConcordat],Taurian Concordat]]. That's where I grew up.

I'm not sure if this is the kind of stuff you were hoping to hear, but we can talk about whatever. I'm not shy.

branches.responseText: Where in the Concordat are you from?
Where'd you learn to pilot a Leopard, anyway?
What can you tell me about House Meyer?
Your family came from Rasalhague?
I'd like to talk about something else.

nodes.text:
I grew up on New Vandenberg. It's a nice enough place, I suppose.

Do you like birds?

branches.responseText: Sure, I guess.
Not particularly.
Why do you ask?

nodes.text:
Then you'd like New Vandenberg. It's basically one big aviary.

Something like two-thirds of the native fauna has feathers, flutters on the wind, and splatters its excrement across every available surface.

Naturally, the original colonists adopted the feathery little monsters into the culture, and those of us that came after were kind of… stuck with it.

Statues, fountains, murals… you name it. Just a giant, feathery pile of screeching alien birds. If the system had a motto, it'd be "Squawk."

branches.responseText: Cute.
I get the picture.
I dunno, it doesn't sound all that bad to me.

nodes.text: Maybe if I hadn't grown up with it.

You sure? Because I could keep going.

I hate birds, is what I'm saying. That may be an unpopular opinion for a pilot, but I'll stand by it until the day I die.
Try living there. I give you about six months of having your lunch stolen by gulls and your head shat on by finches before you change your tune.

Then do yourself a favor and avoid New Vandenberg. Avoid it like the plague.

Something like two-thirds of the native fauna has feathers, flutters on the wind, and splatters its excrement across every available surface.

Because New Vandenburg is crawling with them. It's basically one big aviary.

Something like two-thirds of the native fauna has feathers, flutters on the wind, and splatters its excrement across every available surface.

The Taurian Naval Institute, on New Vandenberg. Well, among other places—it's a big campus. The low-gravity training station orbiting Lompoc was my second home for a time.

TNI flight training isn't usually open to civilians, but my parents had good credit back then, and they could name-drop [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreThomasCalderon],Protector Calderon]]. That'll get you pretty far in the Concordat… for a while, anyway.

The other cadets in my class weren't especially happy sharing air with a civvy, but they couldn't say much. I was nobility and they weren't.

Everyone sort of kept me at arm's length, so I had plenty of time to concentrate on my studies.

I got my certification in both DropShip and JumpShip operation in four years. I even tried working on a commercial jump crew for a while, once upon a time.

The people were fun, but it wasn't for me. The ratio of flying to violent jump sickness skewed hard in the wrong direction.

You're looking at it. My parents are both gone—blood cancer and heart disease, respectively. Both treatable, but they were out of money at that point, so into the ground they went.

Ditto my brother David, who ran off to serve in the [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[Lore3rdSuccessionWar],Third Succession War]] and never came back.

branches.responseText: I'm sorry.
I'm no stranger to loss myself.
That's a rough break.

nodes.text:
The galaxy was at war for nearly two hundred years, Commander. People died. You don't need to apologize for it.

…And truthfully, I was never really all that close to any of them.

David was thirteen years older than me, and had a foot out the door before I turned three. And my parents, well… they raised me by proxy, in the traditional noble fashion. There was no real bond there, even when I was young.

None of this is to say that my folks were bad people. They weren't! They were just… doing what they knew. Their upbringings had been outsourced, just like mine was.

Anyway, that's all I've got to say about my family. They're gone, I'm here, the end.

So… you got another question? Or should we get back to our duties?

Yeah, I'm sure you're not.

Nobody is, really. It's a rough galaxy.

It is what it is.

To be perfectly honest, I was never really all that close to any of them.

It was a long time ago, but yeah. As my parents told it, we were landowners on Pomme De Terre… it's an agricultural world, sort of the breadbasket of the [[DM.Factions[faction_Kurita],Draconis Combine]].

…And yes, I know that "Pomme De Terre" means "potato." My ancestors came from the planet Potato. It took some time for me to accept that, but hey, here we are.

…Anyway. Moving on. House Meyer's holdings were meager, but the value of that land was astronomical. For minor nobility, we were really very wealthy.

And then the Third Succession War broke out, and the political rhetoric got ugly. House Meyer didn't want a single part of what was happening, so my ancestors emptied their accounts and ran.

As a rule, [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreHouseKurita],House Kurita]] takes a really dim view of nobles who cut and run. Words like "traitor" and "defector" start getting thrown around. In the Combine, you really don't want to be on the receiving end of allegations like that. I wouldn't be standing here today if [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreHouseCalderon],House Calderon]] hadn't granted my ancestors asylum in the Concordat. In all likelihood, House Meyer would've been wiped out before I was even born.
Be my guest. What do you need?
